Award.AwardTitle: Robust State and Uncertainty Estimation for Unmanned Systems in the Presence of External Uncertainties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a framework for estimation of motion states and uncertain external inputs for feedback control of unmanned vehicles operating in poorly known environments. This framework will specifically address uncertainties due to uncertain external inputs, sensor noise in motion sensors, and time delay in feedback control. A global treatment of vehicle dynamics will make it possible to estimate and control the motion of rapidly maneuvering vehicles in the presence of uncertainties. The estimation schemes are deterministic, but approximate the underlying probability density function describing the uncertainty in the dynamics of the vehicle. A robust control scheme using the estimates of states and uncertain inputs in the presence of bounded time-delay will be formulated to stabilize and control the vehicle. A computational algorithm, based on a discrete-time interpretation of mechanics, will be used to implement the estimation and control schemes in real-time. Deliverables include software implementations of the components of this framework, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

The proposed research will directly impact applications of unmanned systems in poorly known environments. Example applications include space exploration, satellite geodesy, data gathering from tropical storms, underwater pipeline leak detection, and search and rescue missions. Software made possible through this research will offer improvements to the reliability of unmanned systems used in such applications. In particular, results from this research will (1) improve characterization of uncertain inputs affecting the motion of unmanned vehicles, (2) enable the unmanned vehicle to learn and adapt to the uncertainties in its environment, and (3) characterize and exploit time delay in motion control. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. An educational website will be developed to disseminate research results to students, experts, and the community at large.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research led to the development of autonomous navigation and control schemes for maneuverable unmanned vehicles in the presence of sensor noise, disturbance inputs, and time delays in communications or in feedback control. These schemes were the result of theoretical and numerical advances that were made during this research project. When implemented onboard unmanned vehicles, these schemes will increase their reliability in autonomous operations. This in turn will open up these vehicles to a wide range of applications and make them more reliable and safe for autonomous operations.

During the course of this project, there were several advances made in the understanding of stable autonomous control of unmanned vehicles in the presence of sensor measurement noise, disturbance forces and torques, and time delays in communications or in feedback control. These research findings include: (1) control schemes for attitude control in the presence of time delay; (2) formation control schemes for vehicles in three-dimensional rotational and translational motion with decentralized collision avoidance; (3) robust estimation schemes that can estimate the position, orientation and velocities of an unmanned vehicle based on visual and inertial measurements without requiring precise knowledge of the dynamics of the vehicle; (4) state and parameter observers that can estimate parameters occurring linearly in a known dynamics model for three-dimensional rotational and translational motion; and (5) finite-time stable observers and controllers for rigid body three-dimensional translational and rotational motion. These results were disseminated to the research community through several journal and conference publications. This project also partly supported five doctoral students during different stages of their doctoral studies.

Three techniques for motion estimation and control of unmanned vehicles were developed during this project. These techniques are: (1) a technique to prove stability of motion control schemes in the presence of an unknown but bounded time delay; (2) a technique for stable motion estimation and control that guarantees disappearance of estimation errors and tracking errors in a finite amount of time; and (3) a technique for stable estimation of the motion states in the absence of a dynamic model that can be implemented onboard unmanned vehicles with low computational expense. A comprehensive and rigorous framework for analyzing the stability of unmanned vehicles in the presence of bounded but unknown time delay, and bounded but unknown disturbance forces and moments, was developed during this research. 

Research results from this project were reported in several reputed technical journals and conferences in the area of nonlinear control and dynamics. Eighteen journal papers and over 30 peer-reviewed conference papers were published on research related to this project. Several of these publications have already been cited by researchers in this area all over the world. The motion estimation and control schemes developed during this project are also being transitioned to practice by the investigating team and their collaborators. In addition, a novel attitude control device that works by internal momentum transfer, was invented during this research and patent applied for this invention. This attitude control device has been termed the adaptive singularity-free control moment gyroscope. 


Last Modified: 11/07/2015
Modified by: Amit K Sanyal
